docs.lead_paragraph: 1:17 a.m. | Updated Mitt Romney is scheduled to announce his vice-presidential candidate on Saturday in Norfolk, Va., with several signs pointing toward Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin emerging as the leading candidate for the position.Mr. Romney is set to disclose the selection as he tours the battleship U.S.S. Wisconsin at 8:45 a.m. on Saturday, the campaign announced Friday evening. The announcement ends a four-month search for a running mate on the opening day of a four-day bus tour through four critical battleground states.

headline.main: Romney Is Ready To Name Choice Of Running Mate

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney is scheduled to announce his vice presidential candidate on August 11, in Norfolk, Va, with several signs pointing toward Representative Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin as the leading candidate for the position; announcement will end a four-month search for a running mate on the opening day of a four-day bus tour through four critical battleground states. Photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aggressive action by Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s top banking regulator, against the British bank Standard Chartered has some wondering about his tactics and his ultimate goals.

headline.seo: Regulator Shines Spotlight on a Bank, and on Himself
headline.main: Regulator Shines a Spotlight on a Bank, and on Himself
headline.print_headline: Regulator Shines a Spotlight on a Bank, and on Himself

docs.abstract: Aggressive action by Benjamin M Lawsky, New York’s top banking regulator, against the British bank Standard Chartered has some wondering about his tactics and his ultimate goals; he has drawn both flattering and critical comparisons to his predecessors, including Eliot Spitzer; some officials view his action as the product of political ambition, while others laud Lawsky's aggressiveness.
docs.snippet: Aggressive action by Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s top banking regulator, against the British bank Standard Chartered has some wondering about his tactics and his ultimate goals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Under the health care law, insurers must issue refunds if less than 85 percent of premiums pay for care. But people on employer plans may have to wait for the cash, if they see it at all.

headline.seo: Health Insurance Refunds May Stall in Employers’ Hands
headline.main: Health Insurer Refunds May Stall in Employers’ Hands
headline.print_headline: Delay in Insurance Refund May Lie With Employers

docs.abstract: Millions of workers whose health insurance is covered by their employer are wondering if they will see any direct payments from $1.1 billion in premiums that have been returned to corporate policy holders under the Affordable Care Act; employers must follow certain rules in distributing the rebates, but many are still deciding how, when or even whether to share the cash with their employees.
docs.snippet: Under the health care law, insurers must issue refunds if less than 85 percent of premiums pay for care. But people on employer plans may have to wait for the cash, if they see it at all.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Best Buy, struggling to deal with competition from Amazon.com and turmoil in its leadership, might have avoided some of its problems by planning for the departure of its chief executive.

headline.seo: Best Buy Suffers for Lack of a Succession Plan
headline.main: Best Buy Suffers for Lack of a Plan
headline.print_headline: Best Buy Suffers For Lack Of a Plan

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris, High & Low Finance column, opines that Best Buy's board, struggling to deal with competition from Amazon.com and turmoil in its leadership, might have avoided some of its problems by planning for the departure of chief executive Brian J Dunn; holds its failure to do so has left the company in a very bad situation, as the search for a permanent CEO goes on.
docs.snippet: Best Buy, struggling to deal with competition from Amazon.com and turmoil in its leadership, might have avoided some of its problems by planning for the departure of its chief executive.

docs.lead_paragraph: The losses in the latest quarter bring total losses to $11.6 billion so far in the agency’s fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30.

headline.seo: Postal Service Reports $5.2 Billion Loss for Quarter
headline.main: Post Office Troubles Mount With $5.2 Billion Quarterly Loss
headline.print_headline: Post Office Troubles Mount With $5.2 Billion Quarterly Loss

docs.abstract: Postal Service reports a $5.2 billion net loss in the quarter ending June 30; had reported $3.1 billion loss in the same period a year earlier; revenue in the quarter fell to $15.6 billion, a decrease of $153 million, or a 1 percent decline; attributes loss to a 2006 law requiring that the agency pre-fund future retirees' health benefits, amounting to a $5 billion payment each year for 10 years.
docs.snippet: The losses in the latest quarter bring total losses to $11.6 billion so far in the agency’s fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30.
